short_description: Spicy chicken stew with berbere spice and boiled eggs.
nutrition_benefits: High protein, anti-inflammatory spices.

short_description: Spongy sourdough flatbread made from teff flour.
nutrition_benefits: High iron teff, probiotics from fermentation.

short_description: Ethiopian steak tartare with mitmita spice and butter.
nutrition_benefits: High protein, iron, B vitamins.

short_description: Spiced chickpea flour stew, a fasting-day staple.
nutrition_benefits: Plant protein, fiber, healthy fats.

short_description: Sautéed beef cubes with onions, peppers, and rosemary.
nutrition_benefits: High protein, iron from beef.

short_description: Ethiopian steak tartare seasoned with mitmita spice and niter kibbeh butter. A celebratory dish for special occasions.
nutrition_benefits: High protein, no carbs. Rich in iron and B12.

short_description: Sauteed beef or lamb with onions and peppers. A quick, flavorful Ethiopian stir-fry.
cooking_tips: Very high heat for proper sear.
nutrition_benefits: Protein-rich and satisfying. Iron from beef.

short_description: Creamy chickpea or lentil stew made from powdered legumes. A staple vegetarian dish during fasting periods.
steps: Cook onions in niter kibbeh until very soft.
nutrition_benefits: Plant protein from legumes. Rich in fiber.

short_description: Ethiopian collard greens sauteed with ginger and garlic. A healthy and flavorful side dish.
steps: Remove stems from greens, chop finely.
Cook until tender but still green.
nutrition_benefits: Vitamin K and calcium from greens. Very nutritious.

short_description: Spicy red lentil stew with berbere spice. A cornerstone of Ethiopian vegan cuisine.
steps: Cook onions without oil until dry.
Add niter kibbeh and continue cooking.
Simmer until lentils are very soft.
nutrition_benefits: High fiber and protein from lentils. Iron-rich.

short_description: Fresh Ethiopian cottage cheese, mild and crumbly. Used as a cooling side with spicy dishes.
steps: Remove from heat, add lemon juice.
nutrition_benefits: Calcium and protein from dairy. Cooling for spicy meals.

short_description: Torn injera sauteed with berbere sauce. A delicious way to use leftover bread.
nutrition_benefits: Energy from carbs. Uses leftovers wisely.

short_description: Mild yellow split pea stew without berbere. A gentle option for those avoiding spicy foods.
nutrition_benefits: Plant protein and fiber. Gentle on digestion.

short_description: Spicy Ethiopian paste made with berbere, honey, and wine. Used as a condiment and cooking base.
cooking_tips: Let rest overnight for best flavor.
Use as dip or cooking sauce.
nutrition_benefits: Antioxidants from spices. Use sparingly.

short_description: Mild lamb stew with turmeric and ginger. A gentler alternative to spicy wots.
cooking_tips: Low and slow for tender lamb.
nutrition_benefits: High protein from lamb. Anti-inflammatory turmeric.

short_description: Ethiopian honey bread baked in a pot. Sweet and aromatic, often served at holidays.
steps: Shape into round, place in pot.
nutrition_benefits: Energy from carbs. Comfort food for celebrations.

short_description: Crispy injera with berbere butter. A simple and addictive snack or side dish.
steps: Toast in dry pan until crispy.
nutrition_benefits: Quick energy boost. Simple and satisfying.

short_description: Ethiopian porridge with spiced butter pool in center. Traditional breakfast food, especially for new mothers.
steps: Fill well with melted niter kibbeh.
Eat by dipping edges in butter.
cooking_tips: Must stir vigorously to prevent lumps.
nutrition_benefits: Sustained energy from complex carbs. Traditional postpartum food.

short_description: Fermented flatbread from enset plant. A staple food in southern Ethiopia.
nutrition_benefits: Fermented for probiotics. Unique regional staple.

short_description: Ethiopian green beans and carrots sauteed with onions and garlic. Simple and healthy vegetable dish.
nutrition_benefits: Vitamins from fresh vegetables. Low calorie and nutritious.
